Aerobic oxidation desulfurization (AODS) is the advanced technology for achieving cleaner fuels but suffers from relatively high temperatures and prolonged reaction times. Here, a supported heterogeneous catalyst was developed by anchoring octamolybdate anions ([Mo8O26]4−, {Mo8}) onto hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN), forming MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN. Benefiting from the double terminal oxygen atoms in {Mo8}, which offer higher oxidative reactivity than the single terminal oxygen atoms in {PMo12} and {Mo6}, and the strong adsorption capacity of h-BN, the catalyst exhibits excellent performance in AODS. Complete removal of dibenzothiophene was achieved at 110 ℃ within 4 h under air (even 120 ℃ in 2.5 h). The catalyst showed good recyclability with stable activity over 8 cycles. Mechanistic studies revealed that superoxide radicals (•O2–) are the dominant active species. Moreover, the catalyst demonstrated practical potential by reducing sulfur content in real diesel from 133 ppm to 48 ppm. This work highlights a structure-function relationship in polyoxometalate-based AODS systems and provides a promising strategy for efficient aerobic oxidation reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Aerobic oxidative desulfurization Double terminal oxygen Hexagonal boron nitride Data availability The data supporting the findings of this study are available in the article and ESI. 1 Introduction SOx released during the combustion of sulfur-containing fuels are a major contributor to acid rain, haze and other health hazards. To address these issues, regulations have been implemented to limit sulfur content in fuels to below 10 ppm. Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is the conventional industrial desulfurization technology used to reduce sulfur content but suffers from harsh operating conditions (2 − 10 MPa, 300−350 ℃) and low reactivity toward aromatic sulfides [1] Thus, the development of non-hydrodesulfurization technologies has emerged as supplementary processes to overcome these issues, including adsorptive desulfurization (ADS), [2,3] extraction desulfurization (EDS) [4,5], biological desulfurization (BDS) [6] and oxidative desulfurization (ODS) [7–12] Among them, ODS has attracted significant attention due to its mild conditions and highly efficient removal of thiophene-based sulfide. As research progresses, desulfurization technologies face stricter requirements in multiple dimensions such as efficiency, energy consumption and environmental adaptability. Thus, aerobic oxidative desulfurization (AODS) technology came into being. Molecular oxygen (O2) from the air is an ideal oxidant, as it is abundant, free of harmful by-products, and offers both economic and environmental benefits. However, effectively activating O2 under mild reaction conditions remains a significant challenge. So the selection of highly efficient catalysts is critical for achieving successful AODS. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are a unique class of inorganic compounds with versatile geometric and electronic structural properties that can be controlled precisely [13–15] Polymolybdate, a prominent family of POMs with diverse composition, exhibits excellent multielectron redox capacity and performs good catalytic activity in ODS [16–20] Among them, octamolybdate ([Mo8O26]4−, {Mo8}) has garnered our attention due to the unique double terminal oxygen, which is particularly effective in activating O2 from the air, thereby enhancing ODS performance [21–24] However, these POMs are highly soluble in polar solvents and act as homogeneous catalysts, which are difficult to recover and recycle. In order to solve these problems, POMs are often immobilized on various supports to facilitate heterogeneous catalytic reactions. Hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN), so-called “white graphite”, is isostructural to graphene and consists of alternating B and N atoms [25] With excellent thermal and chemical stability, h-BN is a highly promising candidate for dispersing active substances as a support. Furthermore, the B atom in h-BN possesses empty orbitals, while the S atom in DBT has lone pair electrons, enabling the formation of Lewis acid-base interaction between h-BN and DBT, and thus grants h-BN strong adsorption capacity for DBT [26,27] Therefore, the active substances dispersed on h-BN are brought into close contact with sulfur-containing compounds, significantly enhancing ODS performance. In this study, {Mo6}, {Mo8} and {PMo12} were successfully loaded on h-BN to prepare heterogeneous catalysts with high activity of aerobic oxidation desulfurization, respectively. In the structural systems of {Mo6} and {PMo12}, the terminal oxygen of the metal atom Mo bonds with only a single oxygen atom, and the {MoO8} octahedra are interconnected in a vertex-sharing manner, thereby constructing a single terminal oxygen structure. In contrast, in the {Mo8} structure, the terminal oxygen of the metal atom Mo is linked to two oxygen atoms, and the {MoO8} octahedra are connected to each other in an edge-sharing form, shaping a unique double terminal oxygen structure (Fig. 1 ). The structure characteristics make {Mo8} in catalytic reaction showed higher activity and selectivity. The effects of {Mo8} loading, catalyst dosage and temperature on the performance of the best catalyst (MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN) were investigated. In addition, the underlying free radical mechanism of the ODS reaction was proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalyst [TBA]4Mo8O26 was prepared by the reported literature [28] Na2MoO4∙2H2O (5.00 g) was dissolved in water (12 mL), acidified with 6 M aqueous HCl (5.17 mL), and stirred at room temperature. 1.04 M TBAB solution was slowly dropped into the mixture under continuous stirring for 10 min. The resulting precipitate was filtered and thoroughly washed sequentially with water, absolute ethanol, acetone, and ether, followed by drying in a vacuum. A mixture of commercial h-BN (0.095 g) and CH3CN (30 mL) was ultrasonic for 1 h. Separately, {Mo8} (0.005 g) was dissolved in CH3CN (5 mL) and stirred for 30 min. The two solutions were combined and refluxed at 60 °C for 3 h. Then, the solvent was evaporated at 90 °C and dried in an oven to yield white product denoted as 5 wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN catalyst. 5 wt % Mo6/h-BN, 5 wt % PMo12/h-BN and x wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN catalysts (x = 3, 8, 10) were synthesized in the same way, just changing the POMs and amounts of {Mo8}. 2.2 ODS process The model oil was prepared by dissolving DBT, BT and 4,6-DMDBT in decalin to achieve a sulfur content of 500 ppm. The oxidative desulfurization performance was evaluated in a three-necked flask equipped with a condenser and an air pump. In a typical experiment, 50 mg of catalyst and 40 mL of model oil were added and heated to 110 °C. Then, the air was continuously blown into the reaction system. After the reaction, the residual sulfur content was determined via an internal standard (dodecane, 4000 ppm) method. Samples were collected from the liquid phase at regular intervals, and the concentrations of sulfur compounds were analyzed by gas chromatography-flame ionization detection (GC-FID). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts FT-IR spectroscopy was performed on {Mo8}, h-BN, x wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN, as displayed in Fig. 2(a) . For h-BN, the absorption band centered at 1386 cm−1 can be attributed to the in-plane stretching vibration of B−N, and the peak at 808 cm−1 corresponds to the B−N−B stretching vibration mode [29] In the case of {Mo8}, the bands at 909 and 806 cm−1 are assigned to terminal Mo−Ot and edge-sharing Mo−Oe−Mo vibrations, respectively [30–32] Besides, the band at 661 cm−1 arises from both Mo−Oe−Mo and Mo−Oc−Mo vibrations [33] For x wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN catalyst, the characteristic peak of h-BN can be obviously detected, and with the gradual increase of {Mo8} content, the peak belonging to the {Mo8} structure can also be observed and gradually enhanced. The results show that the intrinsic structures of {Mo8} and h-BN are not destroyed during the synthesis of the catalyst. Fig. 2(b) shows the XRD patterns of the h-BN, {Mo8} and x wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN. The commercial h-BN exhibited two distinct peaks at 26.8° and 41.7°, corresponding to the (002) and (100) lattice plane of h-BN (JCPDS Card No 34–0421) [34] {Mo8} polyoxometalate anion structure shows strong characteristic diffraction peaks in the 5°−10° region. For x wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN, the characteristic diffraction peak of {Mo8} is not prominent, likely due to the low loading of {Mo8} and the dominant diffraction peak intensity of h-BN. Remarkably, as the {Mo8} content increases, the two main peaks of h-BN can still be measured and offset slightly to the right, indicating that the introduction of {Mo8} has no significant effect on h-BN structure. The introduction of {Mo8} in x wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN was further investigated by UV–Vis spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 2(c), an intense signal was found at 204 nm from σ electron excitation of h-BN, and also in x wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN catalysts, implying that the h-BN structure was retentive in catalysts [35] A broad peak corresponding to {Mo8} appeared in the ultraviolet region, and the adsorption of all the x wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN catalysts in the UV region is enhanced. Furthermore, the intensity of the absorption signal strengthened with higher {Mo8} loading, confirming the successful incorporation of {Mo8} into the catalysts. The morphology and structure of the prepared samples were observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM), and results are presented in Fig. 3 . The SEM and TEM images of h-BN reveal its characteristic layered structure (Fig. 3a-b), which provides excellent stability and dispersion as a catalyst support. The h-BN has a lamellar structure about 100 nm in size. This lamellar morphology facilitates the uniform dispersion of the {Mo8} active sites on the h-BN surface, enhancing the activity and stability of the catalyst. Fig. 3(c-d) show that the structure of 5 wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN is similar to that of h-BN, indicating that the h-BN support remains stable after loading {Mo8}. Obvious defect structures on the catalyst surface can be observed by HR-TEM (Fig. 3(f)), and these defect sites have charge transfer interactions with {Mo8}. Specifically, the defect site may change the electron distribution and chemical state of {Mo8} by providing a local electron state, exchanging electrons with the Mo atom of {Mo8}. The charge transfer interaction not only enhances the stability of {Mo8} on the catalyst surface, but also optimizes its catalytic activity. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping in Fig. 3(e) and 3(g-j) further confirms that the Mo element is uniformly distributed, with a low loading amount, demonstrating that {Mo8} is highly dispersed on the h-BN surface. Fig. S1 shows the specific surface area of the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of samples. The isotherm of h-BN exhibits typical II-type curves with a distinct H3 hysteresis loop, confirming its microporous structure. Upon loading {Mo8}, the specific surface area of 5 wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN slightly decreases to 26.06 m2/g compared to that of h-BN. This reduction indicates the successful immobilization of {Mo8} on the h-BN surface, which is consistent with the previous characterization results. According to the structural framework of h-BN (Table S1), the total pore volume of the catalyst decreases to 0.3054 cm3/g compared to h-BN, indicating that {Mo8} may be targeted in the micropores of h-BN. The average pore diameter of the catalyst is increased, which may be caused by the decrease in the number of micropores. The efficient distribution of {Mo8} on h-BN is conducive to exposing more active sites and improving the conversion rate. Elemental compositions and chemical states of samples were investigated by XPS, as shown in Fig. 4 . Peaks corresponding to B, C, N, O and Mo elements were observed in 5 wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN, demonstrating the presence of {Mo8} and h-BN. The high-resolution spectrum of B 1 s (Fig. 4(b)) reveals two peaks at 191.2 eV and 190.5 eV, attributed to B−OH and B−N, respectively [36] Fig. S2(a) shows the C 1 s spectrum of 5 wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN, where the main peak at 284.8 eV corresponds to graphitic carbon, and the peak at 286.2 eV indicates the formation of C = N or CN bonds [35] The peaks around 398.1 eV and 399.6 eV in N 1 s core-level spectra (Fig. 4(c)) are ascribed to N−B bonds and C−N bonds. In the O 1 s core-level spectrum (Fig. S2(b)), two peaks at 530.6 and 532.6 eV can be fitted from the O 1 s curve, assigned to oxygen contamination and −OH groups on the B site, respectively [37] For Mo 3d core level spectrum (Fig. 4(d)), peaks at 231.7 eV and 235.1 eV correspond to MoV, while peaks at 232.7 eV and 235.8 eV correspond to MoVI [38] The spectrum also indicates a peak ratio of MoVI:MoV as 3:1, confirming the presence of six MoVI and two MoV atoms. In addition, the MoVI:MoV ratio in the Mo element of the x wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN (x = 3, 8, 10) catalyst is also 3:1 (Fig. S3). 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalysts 5 wt % PMo12/h-BN, 5 wt % Mo6/h-BN and MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN were prepared by the combination of h-BN with {PMo12} (Keggin), {Mo6} (Lindqvist) and {Mo8} cluster, respectively. A comparison of their desulfurization rates revealed that MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN achieved complete DBT removal. This enhanced performance may be attributed to the presence of double terminal oxygen presented in {Mo8} while the single terminal oxygen in both {PMo12} and {Mo6}, more effectively facilitates the activation of O2, generates active species and accelerates the oxidation process. Sulfur removal using different reaction systems was explored and the results are summarized in Table 1 . Sulfur removal increases from 21.6 % to 100 % when the loading amount of {Mo8} rises from 3 wt % to 5 wt %. However, further increasing the {Mo8} loading to 8 wt % and 10 wt % resulted in dropped to 95.9 % and 62.8 %, respectively. This decline can be attributed to the aggregation of {Mo8} at higher loadings, which limits the exposure of catalytic active sites. As illustrated in Fig. S4, increasing the catalyst loading led to an initial enhancement in reaction rate, which subsequently declined at higher loadings. For comparison, three blank experiments were conducted. In blanks 8 and 9, h-BN and {Mo8} individually achieved Sulfur removal as low as 1.32 % and 0.68 % within 6.5 h, respectively. In blank 7, where the catalyst was a simple physical mixture of {Mo8} and h-BN, the desulfurization efficiency was also poor, at only 4.92 %. The results indicate that the construction of x wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN composites enhances the catalytic activity significantly. In order to further study the relationship between temperature and desulfurization activity, the reaction kinetics of oxidative desulfurization process are studied. The apparent rate constants k at 90 ℃, 100 ℃, 110 ℃ and 120 ℃, are 0.00499, 0.43697, 1.09147 and 2.8955 h −1, respectively (Fig. 5a ). The apparent activation energy of DBT oxidation reaction is 18.5 kJ/mol, according to Arrhenius equation (Fig. 5b). 5 wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN with double terminal oxygen atoms, exhibited lower apparent activation energy, higher k value, and greater catalytic efficiency in oxidative desulfurization. To explore the optimal reaction conditions, the effects of reaction temperature and catalyst amount on desulfurization efficiency were further investigated. Fig. 5(c) illustrates the influence of temperatures on DBT removal. The desulfurization efficiency dramatically improved as the temperature increased from 90 ℃ to 120 ℃. At 110 ℃, the DBT conversion reached 100 % within 4 h. At 100 ℃, sulfur removal was only 51.03 % after 4 h, and achieving deep desulfurization required an extended reaction time of 6.5 h. While complete DBT conversion was achieved within 2.5 h at 120 ℃, 110 ℃ was identified as the optimal temperature for balancing high efficiency with relatively moderate operating conditions. The effect of catalyst amount on DBT conversion was also studied. As shown in Fig. 5(d), the desulfurization efficiency reached 93.6 % when 20 mg catalyst was used, demonstrating the catalyst’s high desulfurization potential. Increasing the catalyst amount to 60 mg enhanced desulfurization efficiency by increasing the number of active sites. However, excessive catalyst addition resulted in poor dispersion, leading to no further improvement in catalytic performance. The highest DBT conversion rate was observed at 50 mg of catalyst, indicating that 50 mg is the optimal amount. Therefore, the optimal reaction conditions were determined to be a reaction temperature of 110 ℃ and a catalyst amount of 50 mg. To investigate the distractions of aromatics and olefins on DBT sulfur removal, methylbenzene and cyclohexene were selected as model compounds and added to oil at a concentration of 15 %. As shown in Fig. 5(e), sulfur removal of 90.3 % and 95.8 % were achieved for oils containing methylbenzene and cyclohexene, respectively, after 4 h of reaction. The results demonstrate that the current aerobic catalytic sulfur oxidation system exhibits excellent resistance to the inhibitory effects of aromatics and olefins. It is well known that various thiophene compounds exist in real diesel. Therefore, the oxidation of two other sulfides, namely 4,6-DMDBT and BT were also tested, and the results are shown in Fig. 5(f). The desulfurization efficiency of the three substrates follows the order: 4,6-DMDBT > DBT > BT. For the electrophilic addition reaction, their oxidation activities might increase with the electron densities on sulfur atoms. As reported, the electron densities on sulfur atoms of the three sulfides decreased in the sequence of 4,6-DMDBT (5.760), DBT (5.758) and BT (5.739), respectively [39] For DBT and 4,6-DMDBT, deep desulfurization (100 %) was reached after 4 h of reaction, while for BT, sulfur removal could reach up to 92.9 % after 5 h. All the above data demonstrate that this reaction system has excellent catalytic oxidation desulfurization performance for different substrates. A comparison of previously reported AODS processes under air/O2 conditions is presented in Table 2 . Many of the heterogeneous catalysts involving POMs, metal oxides, or nanoparticles required pure O2, elevated reaction temperatures, or extended reaction time to achieve complete sulfide conversion. Compared with the reported catalysts, the 5 wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN could achieve deep desulfurization in a relatively low temperature (110 ℃) and shorter reaction time (4 h), demonstrating a significant competitive advantage across multiple parameters. ICP (Inductively Coupled Plasma) spectrum analysis shows that the mass fraction of Mo in 5 wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN is 1.69 %, and the mass fraction of [Mo8O26]4− anion in the catalyst is 2.61 % (Table S2). The turnover frequency (TOF) of 5 wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN is 149.81 h −1. 3.3 Possible reaction process The reusability of the catalyst was carried out to assess the stability of 5 wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN, and the results were displayed in Fig. 6(a) . The sulfur oxidation activity showed no significant decrease, with sulfur removal was 97.93 % after 8 recycling cycles. This result illustrated the excellent recycling performance and reusability of the as-prepared catalyst in this reaction system. And the hot filtration experiment was carried out after the catalyst was cycled several times (Fig S5). During a new round of oxidative desulfurization, the catalyst was filtered out after 1 h of reaction. The desulfurization rate did not increase after continued reaction for 3 h, indicating that the active component Mo was not leached, which further proved the stability of the catalyst. Electron spin resonance (ESR) and radical quenching experiments were conducted to identify the active intermediates in the ODS process. In Fig. 6(b), a series of multi-fold peaks could be found, indicating the generation of superoxide radicals. The radical quenching experiments using p-benzoquinone (BQ, a superoxide radical quencher) and tert‑butanol (TBA, a hydroxyl radical quencher) further confirmed the presence of superoxide radicals. As shown in Fig. 6(c), the addition of TBA has little effect on desulfurization, whereas the addition of BQ significantly reduced the desulfurization rate, indicating that superoxide radicals (•O2−) are captured and play a critical role in the reaction. In the AODS process, the XPS measurement results show that there are mixed valence states MoV and MoVI of Mo element, which is conducive to the activation of O2. The activation of O2 is essential to increase the conversion rate. {Mo8} not only has active sites but also has double terminal oxygen in its own structural framework, which can activate O2 more quickly and effectively. Based on this, the possible reaction mechanism is proposed (Fig. 6d). During catalyst synthesis, electron transfer occurs from h-BN to {Mo8}, reducing MoVI to MoV. In the presence of h-BN support, the sulfur substrates in the oil phase are adsorbed onto the catalyst surface, minimizing the mass transfer pathway. The Mo active site with double terminal oxygen activates O2 to generate •O2−, which oxidizes MoV back to MoVI. The resulting reactive oxygen species attack DBT, forming the intermediate DBTO, which is subsequently oxidized to the corresponding sulfone DBTO2. 3.4 Catalytic performance of real diesel In the real oil desulfurization experiment, the total sulfur content was significantly reduced from 133 ppm to 48 ppm after the oxidation extraction desulfurization process with air as a green oxidant (Fig. 7 ). Real oil contains a complex mixture of sulfur and various non-sulfur impurities, which could significantly inhibit desulfurization efficiency. Nevertheless, the catalyst demonstrated a high tolerance toward such interference, maintaining substantial activity under ambient air conditions. This work thus presents a cost-effective and environmentally benign strategy for the desulfurization of industrial fuel oils, offering promising prospects for practical implementation. 4 Conclusions In summary, a 5 wt % MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN heterogeneous catalyst was successfully prepared by loading {Mo8} onto h-BN. The catalyst, featuring mixed-valence Mo species (MoV and MoVI) and unique double terminal oxygen atoms, exhibited superior O2 activation and excellent AODS performance under atmospheric air. As a result, deep desulfurization of DBT and 4,6-DMDBT was achieved at 110 ℃ within 4 h. The catalyst also showed good resistance to interference such as olefins and aromatics, and demonstrated excellent recyclability with no significant performance loss over 8 cycles. In addition, it displayed promising activity toward real fuel desulfurization. Although 110 ℃ enables efficient conversion in a short time, it remains a relatively high operating temperature. Achieving effective O2 activation at lower temperatures is still a challenge. This study provides a basis for the rational design of low-temperature, energy-efficient AODS catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Aerobic oxidation desulfurization (AODS) is the advanced technology for achieving cleaner fuels but suffers from relatively high temperatures and prolonged reaction times. Here, a supported heterogeneous catalyst was developed by anchoring octamolybdate anions ([Mo8O26]4−, {Mo8}) onto hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN), forming MoV 2MoVI 6/h-BN. Benefiting from the double terminal oxygen atoms in {Mo8}, which offer higher oxidative reactivity than the single terminal oxygen atoms in {PMo12} and {Mo6}, and the strong adsorption capacity of h-BN, the catalyst exhibits excellent performance in AODS. Complete removal of dibenzothiophene was achieved at 110 ℃ within 4 h under air (even 120 ℃ in 2.5 h). The catalyst showed good recyclability with stable activity over 8 cycles. Mechanistic studies revealed that superoxide radicals (•O2–) are the dominant active species. Moreover, the catalyst demonstrated practical potential by reducing sulfur content in real diesel from 133 ppm to 48 ppm. This work highlights a structure-function relationship in polyoxometalate-based AODS systems and provides a promising strategy for efficient aerobic oxidation reaction.
